summary: J. Barry Harrelson was a CIA official involved in the review and release of JFK assassination records to the Assassination Records Review Board (ARRB). He served as a key point of contact between the CIA and the ARRB, addressing issues related to document declassification, protection of sensitive information (such as human sources, covert operations, and cryptonyms), and CIA proposals regarding alias documentation and accommodation addresses. Harrelson summarized ARRB meeting results, conveyed CIA positions on document releases, and coordinated security clearances for ARRB staff. His work spanned from at least 1994 to 1998, focusing on balancing transparency with national security concerns and CIA operational interests. He was involved in discussions regarding the release of information pertaining to CIA stations, foreign government liaison, and specific individuals and operations related to the JFK assassination.
significance: J. Barry Harrelson's significance lies in his role as a key liaison between the CIA and the ARRB during the declassification of JFK assassination records. He was instrumental in navigating the complex process of releasing information while protecting sensitive intelligence sources, methods, and ongoing operations. His memoranda provide insight into the CIA's concerns and strategies regarding the release of JFK-related documents.
